author: Darth_Brickious
title: Fairys FTW
review:
Pros

  • Looks great and /or cute
  • If your the parent of a young girl giving her this will score you HUGE points.

Cons

  • The skirt is a little fiddly to apply even for an adult but it is made of a durable material so shouldn't rip.

Girls will love this minifig, boys maybe not but I suspect it will be one of the harder ones to collect. We felt very lucky that we got hold of it easily.

author: tkettle9719
title: Tinker Bell... In Lego Form!
review:
I got this set a couple of weeks ago at my local Target, and hadn't found time to do a review, so I've decided to do it right now. I got this fairy along with the series 8 DJ for regular price. I opened it, and was rather surprised at the fact that Lego would ever make a fairy. However, this is an excellent rendition of the mythical being. 

Pros

  • This feels very Disney-ey to me; like an original Lego version of Tinker Bell. 
  • The colors on here are outstanding; they are bright greens and blues, transparent in the case of the wings, and the pink wand is relatively cool. 
  • The overall appearance is just cool; the addition of the wings and wand just make the whole thing work. 

Cons

  • I do feel that the wand is too poppy; it just doesn't work with the rest of the accessories or clothing, in my opinion. 
  • I also feel that the skirt is ridiculously difficult to put on; it looks great when you put it on, but it's too much of a hassle to make it perfect. 
  • I feel that the head and hair don't feel all that fairy-ey to me; it feels sort of normal once the face smear is taken off. 

The fairy is a nice addition to the minifigure collection; it's the first female figure that's actually cool and unique, and the fairy has that Disney quality. However, the set has difficulties when applying and it feels a bit too human. I recommend it to those who are into Castle or Fantasy sets; maybe even for Zelda MOCs.

author: Odeinoichus
title: I do believe in Fairies.
review:
Set #8833 Fairy: This is just a beautiful Mini-Figure, seriously she's got to be one of the best new ideas from LEGO in the CMF series for Female Mini-Figs. And so obvious.

The Fairy is dressed in a blue top with a flower pin on her top, already I can envision this Torso print being used in MOCs for Prom or Wedding/Bridal Parties. She also has a great new wing piece in transparent blue, although is it truly new? We haven't seen it before in Bellville have we? No I don't think so. I'm hoping to see way more colors for this piece in new sets, perhaps with the Disney license we'll see some Disney Fairies sets in the future.

She's carrying a wizard's wand in transparent pink, and using the same hairpiece as the flamenco dancer. And of course there's the waist cloth piece for a skirt. A bit of a tricky piece to get on correctly, children may require assistance when putting it on. Overall I'd have to say getting the Fairy Mini-Figure from Series 8 is definitely one you can't pass up, especially for great MOC Potentials.

author: sideswinger
title: simply, GREAT!
review:
The ninth figure in the LEGO Minifigures Series 8 is the Fairy. She was released in 2012, retailed for three dollars, and includes 8 pieces. So let's take a closer look!

On top, we have that Series 4 Ice Skater hair in a fantastic nougat colouring, which appears to be new for the figure in that colouring. I love the wavy moulding on the front, and that bun in the back of the hair looks great as well. I do like the choice of using that hair piece, since it fits the “fairy” trope to me.

Next is her head piece, which has some nice printing. I like the pink lipstick, and of course, that little flower detailing adds a lot to the figure for me. She has no alternate expression, which is okay.

Next is her wings, and I deeply apologise, but my knowledge on if that piece was new or not isn't present. I simply have no idea! But they look gorgeous on her, especially in that translucent light-blue colouring. I love a lot of things about that piece: I like how theirs two segments; one larger part and a smaller part, both of which are split down the centre. And fairy wings are absolutely necessary for her, so they're used very appropriately here.

Next is her torso, which also sports some good printing. I love the leafy-texture printing on the light blue part, and how they resemble straps; and that large, pink flower on the upper-right corner is also a great addition. She has no back printing, but thankfully, the torso is caste in light blue which is accurate to the front torso.

Next is her skirt piece. Here on Brickset, I've seen some reviews that complain about it being pretty finicky to attach on her legs. I don't own this figure, but I can understand how annoying it could be. However, it looks splendid on her, especially with its spring green colouring that contrasts well with the rest of the figure. I also really love the pointy bottoms it has.

Next are her legs, which actually have some light blue printing on the top, underneath that skirt. It's hard to see, but it is indeed there.

Lastly, we have her wand. Once again, unfortunately, my knowledge on if it was new or not is non-existent. Nevertheless, it's a great piece, especially in that translucent pink colouring. I love how that piece has the star on top as well; it's just a fantastic accessory.

That is it for this minifigure! Overall, I do really love the concept, as it presents a very fresh idea in the world of CMF. She also has some nice, useful pieces that I have to appreciate. But actually, this figure is great just because of how well-done she is in general, with the great hair, head, wings...well, everything about her is great! So overall, I will give her a 5 out of 5 rating. That's all for this review. Thanks for reading!
